summary: This document is an email chain between defense attorney Laura Menninger and a federal prosecutor regarding discovery issues in the US v. Maxwell case. The correspondence focuses on problems with metadata, file matching, and access to photographic evidence recovered from CDs at Epstein's residence. The defense raises concerns about corrupt files, insufficient indices, and inability to properly review discovery materials.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell; raises multiple discovery deficiencies regarding photo evidence and metadata matching issues.

events.title: Photo evidence production
events.description: Government produced photographic evidence from CDs recovered from Epstein's residence, designated as SDNY_PROD011.

events.title: Discovery deficiencies raised
events.description: Laura Menninger sends detailed email outlining critical problems with photo evidence discovery, including corrupt files, insufficient metadata, and inability to review materials.

locations: Epstein's residence (source of CDs containing photographic evidence)
Denver, CO 80203 (Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. office)
New York, NY 10007 (Southern District of New York office)
MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center, where Maxwell was held)
keyFacts: The defense identified significant discovery deficiencies including corrupt Excel spreadsheets, mismatched metadata, and inability to properly match photo files with their corresponding metadata.
Photographic evidence was recovered from CDs at Epstein's residence and produced as SDNY011, containing 40,567 files with non-nude images.

The government designated some photos as 'highly confidential' containing 'nude, partially-nude, or otherwise sexualized images' but defense counsel stated they did not observe child pornography among what they could view.
There were discrepancies between file counts in the production (40,567) and the non-nude index (40,536), with hash value mismatches preventing proper file matching.
The defense requested production of all 'highly confidential' images to properly prepare their case, noting the extraordinary cost and burden of reviewing them only in government offices.
